para.para: If one or more of your Swift Object or PAC nodes has experienced an issue, such as power loss or hardware failure, and you need to perform disaster recovery then we provide different scenarios and how to resolve them to get your cloud repaired.

sidebar.para: Typical scenarios in which you will need to repair a Swift object or PAC node include:

listitem.para: The node has either shut down or been rebooted.
The entire node has failed and needs to be replaced.
A disk drive has failed and must be replaced.

sidebar.para: These scenarios are covered in the sections below:

para.link: What to do if your Swift host has shut down or rebooted
How to replace your Swift node
How to replace a hard disk in your Swift node

sidebar.title: What to do if your Swift host has shut down or rebooted
sidebar.para: If your Swift host has power but is not powered on, from the lifecycle manager you can run this playbook:

listitem.para: Log in to the lifecycle manager.
Obtain the name for your Swift host in Cobbler:
Power the node back up with this playbook, specifying the node name from Cobbler:
listitem.screen: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-power-up.yml -e nodelist=<node name>

sidebar.para: Once the node is booted up, Swift should start automatically. You can verify this with this playbook:
Any alarms that have triggered due to the host going down should clear within 10 minutes. See if further assistance is needed with the alarms.

sidebar.title: How to replace your Swift node
sidebar.para: If your Swift node has irreparable damage and you need to replace the entire node in your environment, see for details on how to do this.
